course.subject: LIFS
course.name: Biotechnological Application of Recombinant DNA Techniques
course.description: Practical and theoretical consideration of recombinant DNA techniques, including plasmid construction, PCR, mutagenesis, transformation, sequencing, and bioinformatic analysis. The use of recombinant DNA for protein expression. Graded P or F.
course.prerequisites: LIFS 2040 AND LIFS 2210

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.title: A final-exam course.
reviews.comment_content:
A lab series on different recombinant DNA techniques. All labs will be conducted in groups of 2 to 3 students.

Topics included:
1️⃣ Plasmid Analysis
      🔶 Plasmids as Cloning Vectors
      🔶 Plasmids as Expression Vectors
      🔶 Choice of Restriction Endonucleases
      🔶 Choice of Agarose Gel Resolution
2️⃣ Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)
      🔶 Primer Design
      🔶 Choice of DNA Polymerase
      🔶 Applications of PCR
3️⃣ DNA Cloning
      🔶 Cloning by Restriction Enzymes and DNA Ligases
      🔶 Gibson Assembly
      🔶 Gateway Cloning
4️⃣ Bacterial Transformation
      🔶 Natural Transformation
      🔶 Chemical Transformation
      🔶 Electroporation Transformation
      🔶 Selection by Antibiotics
      🔶 Satellite Colonies
5️⃣ Plasmid Mini-prep
      🔶 Alkaline Lysis Protocol
      🔶 Phenol Extraction
      🔶 Ion-exchange Chromatography
      🔶 Guanidinium Thiocyanate and Silica Method
      🔶 Ethanol Precipitation
      🔶 CTAB Method
      🔶 CsCl Density Gradient Centrifugation
      🔶 PEG Precipitation
      🔶 Plasmid Amplification by Chloramphenicol
6️⃣ QuikChange Site-directed Mutagenesis
      🔶 DNA Sequencing
      🔶 Thermal Cycling
      🔶 Gibson Infusion
7️⃣ Quantitative Analysis of Fluorescence Emission
      🔶 Green Fluorescent Protein (GFP)
      🔶 SDS-PAGE
      🔶 Spectrofluorometer

We've also got to familiarize ourselves with the basic use of ApE, standing for "A Plasmid Editor", a freeware specialized in comparison and analysis of plasmid sequences.
reviews.comment_teaching:
✅ Prof Eugene HUNG is a very nice and passionate professor. He basically outlines the lab protocols and highlights a few key points to be noted during the experiments.

✅ The lab TAs are generally very nice as well and they're willing to reach out for help when we're uncertain with certain parts of the lab.

❌ Prof NGUYEN's tutorials are, however, not easy to understand due to his heavy Vietnamese accents. His slides are basically pictures without descriptions and this causes a lot of troubles when reviewing his slides.
reviews.comment_grading:
Basically a final-exam course. 65% of the course weighting is attributed to the written final exam.

✏️ 21% Lab worksheets
🧪 14% Lab performance
✏️ 65% Written final

The final exam is very confusing. Even if you've done the revision you still have no idea what the heck is going on.

Example of exam questions:
🔷 Definition of 1 unit of enzyme
🔷 Calculation of concentration/volume of a reaction mix
🔷 Calculation of annealing temperature of a given primer
🔷 The procedure of QuikChange site-directed mutagenesis and the involved enzymes
🔷 4 different ways to differentiate 2 plasmids with different antibiotic-resistant genes
🔷 Satellite / "star" colonies
🔷 Gibson assembly cloning vs restriction enzyme cloning

And also a bunch of "interesting" questions that will fuck you up in the exam haha.

💯 Final grade: A-

Who knows what happened to my final exam… I estimated that I only knew about 20% of the questions(?)
reviews.comment_workload: There are a total of 7 lab sessions and 7 lab worksheets submitted one week after each lab session. The lab worksheets are basically 3 to 4 questions on how we analyze the experimental results and how we troubleshoot the problems in case certain problems appear. Overall pretty light workload considering that this course is now worth 3 credits.

reviews.author: Mcdreamy
reviews.comment_content:
有7個lab,教你整返個plasmid 出黎,mutant 佢,又culture 佢等等
都係跟manual 做,講解都清晰
reviews.comment_teaching:
我個session由eugene講introduction, 易明,後期改左由AMY 講,正正常常
中間等pcr/gel個d時間會有個tutorial,佢d英文好重口音,好難明,個身掛住個咪但收唔到音,坐後面會聽得唔清潔,所以有人會行前d聽
reviews.comment_grading:
好難,因為今年停課,所以最後兩個lab冇做,但都要考
final 有兩份卷,兩份都要做,OPEN BOOK, 但都好鬼難, 份卷由朝早8點做到第2朝8點,我差不多由8點到到6點先做完
好彩有得轉P/F,唔係應該炒左
最尾冇出分,直接PASS 左
reviews.comment_workload: 兩星期一個LAB, 上完LAB要寫REPORT, 份REPORT難道適中,除左呢樣冇咩workload

reviews.author: RIbtSU
reviews.title: Fair pass fail course
reviews.comment_content:
1. Amplification of DNA by PCR
2. Plasmid Construction by Gibson Assembly
3. Transformation of Escherichia coli by Plasmid DNA
4. Plasmid Miniprep and Restriction Analysis
5. QuikChange Site-Directed Mutagenesis
6. Quantitative Analysis of Fluorescence Emission by Green Fluorescent Protein
reviews.comment_teaching:
Amy LI was responsible for the practical lab part. She was good in that she explained and stated everything clearly.

NGUYEN was very ＢＡＤ. He was responsible for the tutorial part. His Vietnamese accent was really hard to understand. He seemed to be nervous during tutorials that he sometimes failed even to complete a sentence/ pronounce some words clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Pop quizzes - 18%
Laboratory performance - 12%
Worksheets - 30%
Final examination (40 MCQ + 1 SQ) - 40%

This course is a pass/fail course so basically I didn't study at all for final. I haven't looked at any one of the ppts from canvas throughout the whole semester XD.
The final exam should be mainly asking stuff gone through in that Vietnamese professor's tutorials. Marks are not disclosed for the final exam. I passed anyway.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is optimal I think considering it's a 3 credit lifs lab course. I personally think chem labs , which mostly only account for 1 credit, have a much larger workload.  Just make sure you attended every lab session on time because the penalty for absence seems to be heavy.

reviews.author: Trebmal
reviews.comment_content:
The whole course is to guide you through the steps in creating a plasmid of mutagenized GFP.

1. Amplification of DNA by PCR
2. Plasmid Construction by Gibson Assembly
3. Transformation of Escherichia coli by Plasmid DNA
4. Plasmid Miniprep and Restriction Analysis
5. QuikChange Site-Directed Mutagenesis
6. Quantitative Analysis of Fluorescence Emission by Green Fluorescent Protein

For later steps, you basically spend most of the time waiting in the lab.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Clear instructions by Li during lab.

Did not attend any tutorials so not sure about Nguyen. The audio quality for the tutorial recordings are really poor.
reviews.comment_grading:
Pop quizzes - 18%
Laboratory performance - 12%
Worksheets - 30%
Final examination (40 MCQ + 1 SQ, not sure why that SQ exists) - 40%

Pass / fail, so it's fine as long as you show up during lab sessions punctually, don't break anything, and revise for the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
Average.

The pop quizzes and worksheets are easy if you pay attention to Li during the briefing session.

Though it's mentioned that the final exam will only test on Nguyen's part, it's quite useful to look through the lab manual from Exercise 1 to 6. Each MCQ can have multiple answers so make sure you know what should and shouldn't be going on for each lab procedure.

reviews.author: 山並先生
reviews.comment_content:
1️⃣ Amplification of DNA by polymerase chain reaction
2️⃣ Plasmid construction by Gibson Assembly
3️⃣ Transformation of Escherichia coli by plasmid DNA
4️⃣ Plasmid miniprep and restriction analysis
5️⃣ QuikChange site-directed mutagenesis
6️⃣ Quantitative analysis of fluorescence emission by green fluorescent proteins
reviews.comment_teaching:
NGUYEN 
- strong Vietnamese accent, but his teaching is fine for me.

LI
- explain and demonstrate the step clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
PASS/FAIL

Pop quizzes 18%
Laboratory performance 12% (2% per exercise)
Worksheets 30% (5% per worksheet)
Final examination 40%

* Laboratory performance can be negatively marked if you are absent, break the equipment, etc.
reviews.comment_workload:
biweekly lab report and final (40 MC + 1 short question)

The final only cover Nguyen's part. Most questions are about PCR and multiple answer MCQs. So, make sure you pick all the possible answers.

reviews.author: TimTimTimTim
reviews.comment_content:
Basically the course follow the whole process of how to use the recombinant DNA techniques.  Whole course need to work in 2-3 people groups.

topic :
Restriction Digestion
Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)
Gibson Assembly
Bacterial Transformation
Plasmid Mini-prep
QuikChange Site-directed Mutagenesis
Quantitative Analysis of Recombinant GFP
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Eugene HUNG is nice and willing to asking question not matter how weird your questions are.  He is the one mostly in the lab and help students.  

Prof NGUYEN,  is in charge of the tutorial, although in timetable there is another day for him to taught but eventually he teach in the lab during the waiting time of the lab.  It is hard to listen to what he said due to his accents.  And you need to take your chair to the front if you seat at the back as he use the whiteboard to explain his ppt always
reviews.comment_grading:
65% of the course weighting is attributed to the written final exam.

21% Lab worksheets
14% Lab performance
65% Written final

Well you will get upset when you see the final exam paper.  I got many question not understand . but the grade still A-.
reviews.comment_workload: Only lab report which need to answer the question provided only , lab work not much but do it quick as you need most of the time waiting .

reviews.author: anonymoushehe
reviews.title: (Now a 3 credit course??)
reviews.comment_content: There are in total 8 lab sessions, in which you would learning different recombinant technologies, including aseptic techniques, preparing cell culture, PCR, gibson assembly, site-directed mutagenesis, etc. In addition, you have to attend a 50-minute tutorial each week, where you can learn in-depth knowledge about each kind of recombinant technology. Although the contents aren't directly related to the lab session, i strongly recommend you to attend as they would be tested in the final exam.
reviews.comment_teaching: In the first half of the lab, Bobby would give a pre-lab talk to outline and highlight some key points of the experiment (which is very likely to be tested in the exam). Then he would demonstrate the experiment once. You should find no difficulties in performing the experiment  if you pay attention to bobby's demonstration.
reviews.comment_grading:
Practical exam was cancelled in 2017-18 fall semester. So the grading only depended on lab performance, lab worksheet and final exam (written). The grading is far more lenient than i thought. My group got marks deducted from lab performance for 2-3 times, lab worksheet on average scored around 70-80%, and left ~30% of the final exam blanked, but still got A range at last.
Final exam was disastrous. Short questions consisted of 40%, and the remaining 60% were long questions. No MCQ at all. You have to recite the lab manual and prelab powerpoint in details in order to answer short questions. Long questions only tested for materials taught in tutorial class. They tested for your understanding and application of the technology and it's totally different from the short questions. Simply reciting the tutorial materials had no use at all. As i skipped most of the tutorial class, i found the questions very difficult.
reviews.comment_workload: Similar to other lifs lab that i have taken. 2-3 people in a group (you can form your own group). One lab worksheet for each experiment. Sometimes there are follow-up or pre-lab that require each group to send 1 student to prepare samples for the lab session.

reviews.author: SaT
reviews.title: Introduction to recombinant DNA lab technique
reviews.comment_content: The lab course will include most of the techniques you need for recombinant DNA. This lab course provide an idea of the principles behind that technique and, of course, detailed steps of each technique. This is a course you want to take if you want to learn cloning techniques.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nothing special for Bobby's teaching, just like his usual style in teaching lab course. He will first brief the particular technique and move on to demonstration. Demonstration will be captured by instant camera, but if you need a clearer observation, do come near the demo bench every time. He will explain points you need to pay attention to during experiment. After all, its mainly your time to complete the experiment. You probably will forget the steps and the lab manual can help you a lot.
reviews.comment_grading:
Reasonable grading. Grade mainly contributed by lab reports and final exam.
A really "exciting" final exam. Each beach will have one question, each question will have around 3 minutes to answer and you have to swap to the next bench after 3 minutes passed. The frustrating part is there is no way and no time to come back to answer previous questions. questions type include written and practical questions.
reviews.comment_workload:
Average workload of a lab course. You need to submit one lab report each week. The good news is the lab report is mainly answering questions in the lab manual but a full report is not needed.
The lab report have to be submitted in class, the beginning of class, in the next lab session. So, each lab report you will have a week to complete it.
You will also need pre-lab preparation, sometime you need to spend about 15 min the day before class for preparation.

reviews.author: Hyunggyu kim
reviews.title: LIfs2040
reviews.comment_content:
The content is mainly about sub cellular organelles .
It is from genes to proteins.
This course mainly talks about mechanism inside the cell.
The course syllabus says as follows:

Describe and comprehend important features and functions of the cell nucleus as they relate to
gene organization, DNA replication, protein synthesis and regulation of cell division.
Describe how the amino acid sequences of proteins facilitate protein folding and protein
targeting within the cell.
Describe the features and functions of the endomembrane transport machinery that comprise the
endocytic and exocytic membrane trafficking pathways.
Describe features of biological membrane structures and their transport mechanisms.
Describe important features of the cytoskeleton as well as basic mechanisms of cell
communication and cell division.
Understand the experimental basis / techniques employed in modern cell biological research
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching was very adequate.
Both had well structured the lecture, and the course content was manageable.
However, you might want to review Lifs1902 class notes before taking class because few content requires going back to the high school level biology.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading was very descent.
Although the course was delivered in online mode, Banfield and Guo both managed to teach the class in a very lenient manner.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload as far as I remember wasn't that tough.
The course requires only the midterm and the final.
